text: what's up outliers let's talk about building a trade log if you've heard me on YouTube at all I've talked about this because it is one of the most important things you can possibly do as a Trader so I'm going to walk you through a process of what this whole thing is how it looks and why you should consider it and then I'm going to walk you through an actual example in Google Sheets right now so you can see exactly how to go about building your own now a couple things the first thing is one of the absolute best outputs of building a trade log is the process of building it it's the same thing for building a trading plan the process of building of the log is really useful because it brings you closer to your strategies closer to the information and it makes you think analytically and forecast the kinds of things that you might want to track the other thing about building a trade log is you don't need to have the final solution to start my trade log continues to evolve I just wrapped up my 18th year of trading I went through a phase where it was handwritten then I realized handwritten kind of sucks because you can't conduct data analysis on it so then it went into manual input but that kind of sucked because it was taking me a long time to input all the things that I was

text: have a unbelievable amount of cognitive biases in the way that you perceive information react to information digest and analyze things some of them will be conscious you will be aware of it some of it you won't so the way we use a log is to Short Circuit those to make sure that we're not applying Goldilocks analysis and saying oh yeah you know I thought I made some money on that trade and then when you go back and look including fees it was a loss or if you're an options Trader and you're rolling options for 6 months and you're like man I'm so glad I got out of this thing out of profit but then you realize once you calculate the total returns over that six-month time frame you're like well crap I have essentially nothing to show for it sure I got out of those series of roles for a small profit but then if I look at the overall return on that money for that time frame it's not good so coming to reality with stuff like that is very important now the last Point here is designed to frame a thought for you building a trade log can be overwhelming but if you're planning to trade for a long duration of time a trade log is essentially bookkeeping this is what businesses do this is how businesses make decisions and survive and last the sooner that we accept that there's work to be

text: building a trade log can be overwhelming but if you're planning to trade for a long duration of time a trade log is essentially bookkeeping this is what businesses do this is how businesses make decisions and survive and last the sooner that we accept that there's work to be done as a Trader and if we Embrace this work and get over it and get on board with it the faster you're going to see results so the how what kind of things belong in a trade log the way that my mind buckets it is there are things that we need to track for every individual kind of log we might build then there are elements that are going to be highly specific to the individual strategies that we're building so let me show you what this looks like what I do is use different tabs for different strategies so strategy one gets its own tab strategy two gets its own Tab3 gets its own tab paper trading strategy 1 gets its own tab so on and so forth and then I summarize all of these individual sheets within the tab itself and then also I pull out the requisite detail details into a C2C tab C2C in the military stands for command and control but I want to show you take a look at our sample log that I'm going to be showing you so we have a coverage strangle tab here if you're following the coverage

text: if we take a look at tle Q's you can see that this is the total log here and based on this total log I have about all all of the details I use to make decisions I summarize things on the left hand side for the total position and then I track all of the individual stuff here in the center I split short puts short calls that are open and then I have sections to track the closed versions of those trades then you might ask well why don't I just put the closed up here below this section well it's because I tend to trade more puts than calls so then this would push the call section down too far over time so that I have to scroll a lot again even though I prefer manual inputs I have to be thoughtful about what I'm doing and how I input things so that it's sustainable so then the other thing you'll notice is that there are some sections that are coded in green that represents elements that require my physical input then there are these sections over here which are automatically going to calculate based on these inputs over here so my goal is to make it really really easy for me to see where I need to input information and what information needs to go there so if we take a look you can see for the coverage triangle I'm tracking things like entry dat stock

text: now I'm using 748,000 in terms of allocation in terms of actual utilization I'm only using 532 the difference between allocation is how much money I'm setting aside to do something utilization is how much I'm using at a given point in time then I purpos have a section that takes out box spreads the reason why I want to take out box spreads is because a lot of times box spreads are tied to other trades but it's a place that I park cash to be more efficient then we have notional exposure the reason why we have notional exposure is because if I'm trading leveraged underlyings I want to know what my actual risk is so a good example of that is here in the coverage triangle because as I showed you we're trading uo and tqs so when I'm figuring out what my total exposure is I don't want to just use my actual dollar utilization because even though this is the max I could technically R risk at a given point in time the notional exposure will help me understand how levered I am and give me some sense of the total risk there again this is an aggregate level tab then I have just some Standard Market tracking stuff how far we are off of highs and off of local highs for different indices a watch list and stuff to do and then just some basic calculators over here then this is where I would

text: is an aggregate level tab then I have just some Standard Market tracking stuff how far we are off of highs and off of local highs for different indices a watch list and stuff to do and then just some basic calculators over here then this is where I would continue building out other sections this would actually be input in here so I took it out to make it look a little easier to see but the way that this would actually look is this would go down here then all of this would slide up into this and then all of this would be filled in and I would apply the same lines and all that stuff to make it easy for me to see and each of these would go to the individual tabs to pull together the Futures tab everything that's going on in the Futures Trading space the ratio diagonals and so on and so forth this is literally a step-by-step process on how you build a log you start by the individual tabs you track the things that you need but you make it so that you can conduct broader analysis what I typically do is you'll notice that I set space off to the side here so that I can write different formulas to test different ideas I don't bother with graphs and stuff like that I know people like those kind of visuals I think they're fine but I don't need it
